body: I ran into the same problem, and can't figure out what is causing the warning.  When I look at my backtrace, all I see is Rspec and ActiveSupport code - no other 3rd party gems.

@andyl The tricky part is that some 3rd party is definitely adding a metadata filter based on the `:example_group`, however once it has been added it doesn't get executed until later by RSpec's own filtering code, which is why it manifests as not coming from any 3rd party in the backtrace.
We do want to address this, though, and get it in a patch release.
This error is happening for me as well on every describe block. How do I determine the offending 3rd party gem?
Remove the 3rd party gems until it goes away (pending any specs using those components)

It turns out my issue is related to the draper gem as reported by another user in a related issue. The problem with draper is that it automatically includes it's rspec integration if the RAILS_ENV is test no matter what.

Sadly I suspect you'll need to report this to / open a PR to fix this on Draper and either ignore the deprecations or remain on RSpec 2.x for now. Remember you can pipe deprecation output to a file or an IO object if you want to silence it
Draper's been fixed in drapergem/draper#623.  I don't think there's a release with that yet, though.
Looks like there's a similar fix for pundit in elabs/pundit#156.
Heheh, I saw that as I brought the project up in my editor after forking...doh, I should have checked the closed issues. Thanks. Referencing master works: `gem 'draper', github: 'drapergem/draper'`
Referencing draper/master solved the problem for me.
I'm going to take a stab at this.

This is from a simple `describe SomeClass` block, with no indication of a third-party gem in the backtrace:

@nathany -- based on the back trace I'd say that there is something that has configured `config.include  SomeModule, :example_group => { ... }` or `config.extend SomeModule, :example_group => { ... }`.  You may want use ack or grep to search for references to `:example_group` in your gems as one of them may be the source.

``` ruby
# "view" in presenters
config.include ActionView::TestCase::Behavior, example_group: {file_path: %r{spec/presenters}}
```

switching to this:

``` ruby
config.include ActionView::TestCase::Behavior, :file_path => %r{spec/presenters}
```

Yay! Thanks @myronmarston.

Yep.  For RSpec 3 that can be simplified to:

``` ruby
# "view" in presenters
config.include ActionView::TestCase::Behavior, file_path: %r{spec/presenters}
```
Thanks. I think the error message and the location of where the error came from are a little confusing, but all is working now.

> Thanks. I think the error message and the location of where the error came from are a little confusing, but all is working now.

Yep, it's very confusing.  It's a consequence of the fact that `config.include` just stores the provided hash for later use...and then when it's used later, it tries to access `example_group_metadata[:example_group]`, which triggers the warning, but the original source is not in the backtrace anymore.  I plan to work on a fix this week.
Sounds good. Even having an example like above when Googling for "The `:example_group` key in an example group's metadata hash is deprecated." is helpful.
